elements.content: 5-(6-Carboxypyridin-3-yl)­isophthalic acid (H3L) was utilized as an almost unexplored multifunctional ligand to construct, under hydrothermal conditions, ten new coordination compounds, namely, [Cd­(μ2 -H2L)2] n (1), [Ni­(HL)­(H2biim)2] (2), [Mn­(μ2 -HL) (phen)­(H2O)]2·2H2O (3), {[Mn3(μ4 -L)2(H2O)6]·3H2O} n (4), {[Co3(μ5 -L)2(H2O)6]·2H2O} n (5), {[Ni3(μ4 -L)2(H2O)6]·2H2O} n (6), {[Zn3(μ5 -L)2(H2O)4]·2H2O} n (7), {[Mn3(μ5 -L)2(H2O)6]·4H2O} n (8), {[Co3(μ4 -L)2(μ2-4,4′-bipy)­(H2O)6]·2H2O} n (9), and {[Ni3(μ5 -L)2(H2O)6]·2H2O} n (10), also using an optional auxiliary ligand selected from 2,2′-biimidazole (H2biim), 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), or 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bipy). The obtained compounds 1–10 were analyzed by IR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric and elemental analysis, and single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction. The structures of the products vary from 3D MOFs (metal–organic frameworks 5 and 7–10) to 2D CPs (coordination polymers 1, 4, and 6) as well as to a discrete 0D monomer 2 and a dimer 3. The latter two are extended by multiple hydrogen bonds into complex 3D supramolecular networks. This structural difference in 1–10 is directed by the kind of metal­(II) center, the deprotonation degree of the principal H3L building block, and/or the kind of auxiliary ligand. Notably, an addition of 4,4′-bipy can tune the structures of MOFs 8–10 by the coordination or template effect. Topological classification of metal–organic and H-bonded underlying networks was performed, disclosing a variety of topological nets: sql (in 1), 3,10T3 (in 3), 3,4L83 (in 4 and 6), tcs (in 5, 8, and 10), 3,4,5T95 (in 7), and sra (in 9), as well as a topologically unique network in 2. The magnetic properties (for compounds 3–6, 8–10) and luminescent properties (for compounds 1, 7) were also investigated and discussed. In fact, compound 7 exhibits an intense violet emission in the solid state. Measurements of the magnetic susceptibility indicate interactions of an antiferromagnetic nature between the adjacent metal­(II) centers in the compounds 3–6 and 8–10. The obtained products represent the first series of metal–organic compounds assembled from the H3L precursor, thus opening up its application as a new pyridine–tricarboxylate organic block for designing CPs or MOFs.

elements.content: A new series of ten 0D, 2D, or 3D coordination compounds was synthesized from an unexplored pyridine−tricarboxylate building block and various ancillary ligands (optional). All products were fully characterized and their structural, topological, luminescent, and magnetic properties were investigated.
elements.clean_text: A new series of ten 0D, 2D, or 3D coordination compounds was synthesized from an unexplored pyridine-tricarboxylate building block and various ancillary ligands (optional). All products were fully characterized and their structural, topological, luminescent, and magnetic properties were investigated.

elements.content: The research on CPs (coordination polymers) or MOFs (metal–organic frameworks) has been of increasing popularity in recent years due to their intriguing architectures as well as various properties that open up a vast diversity of applications in different fields. A particularly interesting research topic consists of exploring novel organic molecules as potential building blocks (spacers or linkers) that are capable of providing the metal–organic networks with desirable structural characteristics and functional properties. However, the generation of CPs or MOFs in a predictable manner still remains a difficult task, since the assembly of such compounds can be influenced by a number of key factors, namely, the geometry of metal ions, type of organic building blocks, reaction parameters, template effect, and introduction of ancillary ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The research on CPs (coordination polymers) or MOFs (metal-organic frameworks) has been of increasing popularity in recent years due to their intriguing architectures as well as various properties that open up a vast diversity of applications in different fields. A particularly interesting research topic consists of exploring novel organic molecules as potential building blocks (spacers or linkers) that are capable of providing the metal-organic networks with desirable structural characteristics and functional properties. However, the generation of CPs or MOFs in a predictable manner still remains a difficult task, since the assembly of such compounds can be influenced by a number of key factors, namely, the geometry of metal ions, type of organic building blocks, reaction parameters, template effect, and introduction of ancillary ligands.

elements.content: A high diversity of aromatic polycarboxylate blocks including N-heterocyclic carboxylic acids has been vastly used as multifunctional blocks in crystal engineering of MOFs. Among them, semirigid ligands containing phenyl-pyridine cores with a varying number and position of carboxylic groups and N-pyridyl functionality within the aromatic rings have attracted special interest. This is justified by the possibility of the rotation of two aromatic rings, thus allowing compliance with coordination environment of certain metal ions. Furthermore, the presence of both N-pyridyl and O-carboxylate donor atoms as well as different deprotonaton degrees of carboxylic groups can facilitate the modification of coordination fashions, thus leading to the assembly of metal–organic nets with different structures. Furthermore, these types of organic ligands can be involved in strong hydrogen bonding interactions, which can provide an extra stabilization of structures and facilitate the crystallization of products.
elements.clean_text: A high diversity of aromatic polycarboxylate blocks including N-heterocyclic carboxylic acids has been vastly used as multifunctional blocks in crystal engineering of MOFs. Among them, semirigid ligands containing phenyl-pyridine cores with a varying number and position of carboxylic groups and N-pyridyl functionality within the aromatic rings have attracted special interest. This is justified by the possibility of the rotation of two aromatic rings, thus allowing compliance with coordination environment of certain metal ions. Furthermore, the presence of both N-pyridyl and O-carboxylate donor atoms as well as different deprotonaton degrees of carboxylic groups can facilitate the modification of coordination fashions, thus leading to the assembly of metal-organic nets with different structures. Furthermore, these types of organic ligands can be involved in strong hydrogen bonding interactions, which can provide an extra stabilization of structures and facilitate the crystallization of products.

elements.content: Besides the main organic building blocks, many other components of a reaction system such as coligands and template agents may have an influence on the assembly process of CPs or MOFs. It is well-known that coligands can act as auxiliary moieties, whereas the molecules acting as templates do not bind to metal ions and often do not enter into the final structure, but have a structure-guiding behavior during the self-assembly synthesis. 4,4′-Bipyridine represents one of the most common examples of such a coligand or template agent.

It is well-known that coligands can act as auxiliary moieties, whereas the molecules acting as templates do not bind to metal ions and often do not enter into the final structure, but have a structure-guiding behavior during the self-assembly synthesis. 4,4'-Bipyridine represents one of the most common examples of such a coligand or template agent.

elements.content: Taking into consideration the above discussion and being interested in finding and exploring new multifunctional N,O-building blocks with a phenyl-pyridine core toward the design of metal–organic networks, we have selected 5-(6-carboxypyridin-3-yl)­isophthalic acid (H3L, ) as a poorly explored but very promising building block with multiple functionalities. Hence, in the current work, a number of hydrothermal synthetic experiments using various metal­(II) chlorides (M = Cd, Ni, Mn, Co, or Zn) and H3L has been performed. Some reactions have been carried out using an additional ancillary ligand such as 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bipy), or 2,2′-biimidazole (H2biim). A special attention has been paid to the latter in view of possible coordination and template effects of 4,4′-bipy on the generation of metal–organic nets.

Hence, in the current work, a number of hydrothermal synthetic experiments using various metal(II) chlorides (M = Cd, Ni, Mn, Co, or Zn) and H3L has been performed. Some reactions have been carried out using an additional ancillary ligand such as 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bipy), or 2,2'-biimidazole (H2biim). A special attention has been paid to the latter in view of possible coordination and template effects of 4,4'-bipy on the generation of metal-organic nets.

elements.content: To explore the application of 5-(6-carboxypyridin-3-yl)­isophthalic acid for the generation of various metal–organic or H-bonded networks based on Cd, Ni, Mn, Co, or Zn, we performed a number of reactions under hydrothermal conditions () by allowing to react a mixture composed of a metal­(II) chloride, H3L, and an ancillary ligand or linker; these were chosen from 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), 2,2′-biimidazole (H2biim), or 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bipy). It should be mentioned that a recent study reported the synthesis and structure of the compound 4, which could also be obtained by the hydrothermal reaction of MnCl2·4H2O, H3L, DMF, and water. However, the topological classification, thermal stability, and magnetic properties were not studied and thus are reported in the present work.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

To explore the application of 5-(6-carboxypyridin-3-yl)isophthalic acid for the generation of various metal-organic or H-bonded networks based on Cd, Ni, Mn, Co, or Zn, we performed a number of reactions under hydrothermal conditions () by allowing to react a mixture composed of a metal(II) chloride, H3L, and an ancillary ligand or linker; these were chosen from 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), 2,2'-biimidazole (H2biim), or 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bipy). It should be mentioned that a recent study reported the synthesis and structure of the compound 4, which could also be obtained by the hydrothermal reaction of MnCl2⋅4H2O, H3L, DMF, and water. However, the topological classification, thermal stability, and magnetic properties were not studied and thus are reported in the present work.

elements.content: MOFs 4 and 8 were generated under the same hydrothermal conditions except that 4,4′-bipy was added during the synthesis of 8. Interestingly, 4,4′-bipy can act as a template and tune the coordination modes of L3– blocks, thus changing the resulting structure. To further demonstrate that the template effect of 4,4′-bipy can be extended to other related systems, the starting Mn­(II) salt was replaced by the corresponding Co­(II) or Ni­(II) chlorides. As a result, isomeric MOFs 6 and 10 were obtained. In contrast, a coordination of 4,4′-bipy to Co­(II) is observed in MOF 9 (), in which 4,4′-bipyridine plays a role of μ2-linker. Structures of all the obtained products 1–10 were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and confirmed by conventional methods, namely, by IR and UV–vis spectroscopies, thermogravimetric and elemental analyses, and powder X-ray diffraction.

To further demonstrate that the template effect of 4,4'-bipy can be extended to other related systems, the starting Mn(II) salt was replaced by the corresponding Co(II) or Ni(II) chlorides. As a result, isomeric MOFs 6 and 10 were obtained. In contrast, a coordination of 4,4'-bipy to Co(II) is observed in MOF 9 (), in which 4,4'-bipyridine plays a role of μ2-linker. Structures of all the obtained products 1-10 were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and confirmed by conventional methods, namely, by IR and UV-vis spectroscopies, thermogravimetric and elemental analyses, and powder X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: Compound 1 shows a two-dimensional metal–organic network. The asymmetric unit bears a crystallographically unique Cd­(II) atom (with half occupancy) and one μ2-H2L– block. Eight-coordinate Cd1 center displays a distorted dodecahedral {CdN2O6} environment filled by six O atoms from four different μ2-H2L– blocks and two N atoms from two μ2-H2L– linkers (a). The Cd–O bond distances vary from 2.406(4) to 2.477(3)­Å, whereas the Cd–N distances are 2.355(4)­Å; these bonding parameters agree with those encountered in previously reported Cd­(II) derivatives. In 1, H2L– behaves as a μ2-linker (mode I, ), with the COOH and COO groups showing the η1:η0 monodentate and η1:η1 bidentate modes, respectively. In H2L–, the dihedral angle between the two aromatic rings is 25.54°. The μ2-H2L– linkers connect neighboring Cd­(II) atoms to generate a 2D metal–organic layer; it has a shortest separation between two cadmium­(II) atoms of 12.071(4) Å (b). These two-dimensional layers are extended, via O–H···O hydrogen bonds, to give a 3D supramolecular framework (c and Table S3, ). Topological classification of the 2D CP 1 reveals a uninodal 4-connected underlying layer that is constructed from the 4-connected Cd1 nodes and the 2-connected μ2-H2L– linkers (d). This layer can be classified as the sql [Shubnikov tetragonal plane net] topological net having the point symbol of (44.62).
elements.clean_text:
Description of Structures

[Cd(μ2-H2L)2] n  (1)

Compound 1 shows a two-dimensional metal-organic network. The asymmetric unit bears a crystallographically unique Cd(II) atom (with half occupancy) and one μ2-H2L- block. Eight-coordinate Cd1 center displays a distorted dodecahedral {CdN2O6} environment filled by six O atoms from four different μ2-H2L- blocks and two N atoms from two μ2-H2L- linkers (a). The Cd-O bond distances vary from 2.406(4) to 2.477(3)Å, whereas the Cd-N distances are 2.355(4)Å; these bonding parameters agree with those encountered in previously reported Cd(II) derivatives. In 1, H2L- behaves as a μ2-linker (mode I, ), with the COOH and COO groups showing the η1:η0 monodentate and η1:η1 bidentate modes, respectively. In H2L-, the dihedral angle between the two aromatic rings is 25.54°. The μ2-H2L- linkers connect neighboring Cd(II) atoms to generate a 2D metal-organic layer; it has a shortest separation between two cadmium(II) atoms of 12.071(4) Å (b). These two-dimensional layers are extended, via O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds, to give a 3D supramolecular framework (c and Table S3, ). Topological classification of the 2D CP 1 reveals a uninodal 4-connected underlying layer that is constructed from the 4-connected Cd1 nodes and the 2-connected μ2-H2L- linkers (d). This layer can be classified as the sql [Shubnikov tetragonal plane net] topological net having the point symbol of (44.62).

elements.content: This compound has a discrete monomeric structure with the asymmetric unit containing of a Ni­(II) atom, one terminal HL2– ligand, as well as a couple of chelating H2biim ligands. The six-coordinate Ni­(II) atom is surrounded by one O and one N atom of the HL2– ligand and four N atoms coming from two chelating H2biim blocks (a), thus forming a distorted octahedral {NiN5O} environment. The Ni–O bond length [2.113(3) Å] and the Ni–N bond distances [2.045(3)–2.132(3) Å] are in agreement to the bonding parameters in previously described Ni­(II) compounds. The HL2– functions as a terminal N,O-chelating moiety with its carboxylate functionality being in the η1:η0 monodentate fashion (mode II, ). Dihedral angle of 14.99° is observed between two aromatic rings of the HL2– ligand. Discrete units of 2 are connected by means of strong N–H···O and O–H···O hydrogen bonding interactions to give rise to a three-dimensional supramolecular network (b, Table S3, ). After simplification, this framework can be considered from the topological viewpoint as a uninodal 5-connected net assembled from the mononickel­(II) molecular nodes (c). In spite of being composed of only one type of nodes, this net features an unprecedented topology that is described by the (44.66) point symbol. Search within different databases confirmed an undocumented type of this topology.

[Ni(HL)(H2biim)2] (2)

This compound has a discrete monomeric structure with the asymmetric unit containing of a Ni(II) atom, one terminal HL2- ligand, as well as a couple of chelating H2biim ligands. The six-coordinate Ni(II) atom is surrounded by one O and one N atom of the HL2- ligand and four N atoms coming from two chelating H2biim blocks (a), thus forming a distorted octahedral {NiN5O} environment. The Ni-O bond length [2.113(3) Å] and the Ni-N bond distances [2.045(3)-2.132(3) Å] are in agreement to the bonding parameters in previously described Ni(II) compounds. The HL2- functions as a terminal N,O-chelating moiety with its carboxylate functionality being in the η1:η0 monodentate fashion (mode II, ). Dihedral angle of 14.99° is observed between two aromatic rings of the HL2- ligand. Discrete units of 2 are connected by means of strong N-H⋅⋅⋅O and O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions to give rise to a three-dimensional supramolecular network (b, Table S3, ). After simplification, this framework can be considered from the topological viewpoint as a uninodal 5-connected net assembled from the mononickel(II) molecular nodes (c). In spite of being composed of only one type of nodes, this net features an unprecedented topology that is described by the (44.66) point symbol. Search within different databases confirmed an undocumented type of this topology.

elements.content: Compound 3 exhibits a discrete dinuclear structure with its asymmetric unit containing one Mn­(II) atom, one μ2-HL2–, and one 1,10-phenanthroline moiety, one H2O ligand, and one water molecule of crystallization. A 6-coordinate Mn1 center exhibits distorted octahedral {MnN3O3} geometry which is filled by one N atom and two carboxylate O atoms coming from two different μ2-HL2– blocks, one O atom from water ligand, and two N atoms of a 1,10-phenanthroline moiety (a). Distances of the Mn–O bonds [2.125(2)–2.133(2) Å] and the Mn–N bonds [2.261(3)–2.359(3) Å] are typical for such manganese­(II) compounds. In 3, the HL2– block shows a μ2-mode (mode III, ), wherein both deprotonated COO groups adopt a η1:η0 monodentate mode. Two aromatic rings in HL2– show a dihedral angle of 34.92°. In 3, the μ2-HL2– ligands connect the Mn1 atoms to give a Mn2 molecular unit having a Mn···Mn distance of 9.405(3) Å (a). These discrete Mn2 units and H2O molecules of crystallization are interconnected by means of the O–H···O H-bonds to give rise to an intricate three-dimensional supramolecular network (b, Table S3, ). This network was simplified to carry out the topological classification, resulting in the underlying binodal 3,10-connected net (c). This net has the 3,10T3 topology and is described by the (3.42)2(34.410.514.614.72.8) point symbol, wherein the (3.42) and (34.410.514.614.72.8) indices are those of the 3-conected H2O nodes and the 10-connected dimanganese­(II) molecular nodes, respectively.

elements.content: Compounds 4 and 6 are isostructural. Crystal structure of 6 was selected as a representative example for detailed description. Asymmetric unit of 6 has two different Ni1 and Ni2 centers, a μ4-L3– block, three H2O ligands, and a lattice H2O molecule. Six-coordinate Ni1 atom adopts a distorted octahedral {NiNO5} environment formed by four carboxylate O and one N atom from three distinct μ4-L3– blocks and an O atom of H2O ligand (a). The 6-coordinate Ni2 center is positioned on a twofold rotation axis. Its distorted octahedral {NiO6} environment is filled by two oxygen atoms coming from two distinct L3– moieties and four H2O ligands. The Ni–O bonds vary from 2.114(3) to 2.322(4) Å, while the Ni–N distance is 2.309(4) Å; these bonding parameters are within normal values for related Ni­(II) compounds. In compound 6, the L3– block behaves as a μ4-spacer (mode IV, ), wherein the COO groups exhibit the η1:η0 monodentate and the η1:η1 and μ2-η1:η1 bidentate modes. In L3–, the dihedral angle between aromatic rings is 6.23°. Three adjacent nickel­(II) atoms are interconnected by two COO groups from distinct L3– blocks, resulting in a centrosymmetric trinickel­(II) subunit (b). In this Ni3 unit, the Ni···Ni separation of 5.613(2) Å is close to similar distances observed in other trinuclear carboxylate-bridged nickel­(II) compounds. Neighboring Ni3 subunits are additionally interlinked by the L3– spacers to give a 2D metal–organic network (c). It has the shortest separation of 9.171(2) Å among the adjacent trinickel­(II) subunits and also possesses the channels with a dimension of 6.760 × 9.171 Å2, measured by using atom-to-atom distances. If H2O ligands and lattice molecules are removed, PLATON analysis shows that the network’s free volume represents 27.5% of crystal volume. To perform the topological analysis of this 2D coordination network, a simplified underlying net was generated (d). This net is constructed from the 3-connected Ni1 nodes, 2-connected Ni2 linkers, and 4-connected μ4-L nodes. Topological classification of this net reveals a binodal 3,4-connected layer, which possesses a 3,4L83 topology and the (42.63.8)­(42.6) point symbol. Herein, the (42.63.8) and (42.6) indices are those of the μ4-L and Ni1 nodes, respectively.

elements.content: Compounds 5, 8, and 10 are isostructural; therefore, only 5 is discussed in detail as an example. Its asymmetric unit consists of two crystallographically independent cobalt­(II) centers (Co1 with full occupancy; Co2 is positioned on a twofold rotation axis), a μ5 -L3– block, three H2O ligands, and a water molecule of crystallization. Six-coordinate Co1 atom reveals distorted octahedral {CoNO5} environment, filled by one N and four O atoms from four distinct μ5 -L3– blocks and one H2O ligand (a). The Co2 center is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two distinct L3– moieties and four H2O ligands, thus composing distorted octahedral {CoO6} geometry. The Co–O [2.080(6)–2.182(6) Å] and Co–N [2.144(6) Å] bond lengths agree well with related bonding parameters in other cobalt compounds. The L3– block adopts a μ5-bridging mode (mode V, ), wherein three COO groups reveal the η1:η0 monodentate and the μ2-η1:η1 bidentate fashions. In μ5 -L3–, the dihedral angle among aromatic rings attains 22.82°. The μ5-L3– spacers alternately interconnect the neighboring cobalt atoms to generate a one-dimensional chain motif (b). Such motifs are further interlinked by μ5 -L3– blocks into a 3D MOF (c). Its framework has channels of the 9.803 × 6.500 Å2 size if measuring atom-to-atom distances. After the elimination of H2O ligands and solvent molecules, PLATON analysis indicates that the network has a free volume of 14.8% (relative to the total crystal volume). Analysis of the topology of this three-dimensional MOF reveals a binodal 4,5-connected underlying network (d) with tcs topology. This topology is described by the (44.62)­(44.66) point symbol, where the (44.62) and (44.66) notations are those of the 4-connected Co1 and 5-connected μ5-L nodes, respectively; there are also the 2-connected Co2 centers that act as linkers.

elements.content: The Zn–O [1.959(9)–2.229(6) Å] and Zn–N [2.034(8) Å] bond distances are in agreement with those reported for related zinc derivatives. In 7, the L3– block behaves as a μ5-spacer (mode VI, ) with its COO groups adopting η1:η0 monodentate, μ2-η1:η1 bidentate, and μ2-η2:η1 tridentate modes. In μ5-L3–, dihedral angle between aromatic rings attains 25.67°. Carboxylate groups of the μ5-L3– blocks multiply interconnect neighboring zinc atoms to give rise to an intricate 3D MOF structure (b). It contains channels of the 7.938 × 4.241 Å2 dimension if measured via atom-to-atom distances; these channels are filled with lattice H2O molecules. After the elimination of H2O molecules (both ligand and solvent), PLATON allowed to calculate a network’s free volume of 7.0% (relatively to the total crystal volume). From topological perspective, a simplified underlying three-dimensional network of 7 (c) is defined as a trinodal 3,4,5-connected net of the 3,4,5T95 topology. Point symbol of this net is (4.63.86)2(42.84)­(63)2, wherein the (4.63.86), (42.84), and (63)2 notations correspond to the 5-connected μ5-L nodes, 4-connected zinc­(II) nodes (based on disordered Zn2 atoms), and 3-connected Zn1 nodes, respectively.

elements.content: Asymmetric unit in this structure reveals two different cobalt­(II) centers (Co1 having full occupancy; Co2 being positioned on a twofold rotation axis), one μ4 -L3– block, a half of 4,4′-bipy ligand, three H2O ligands, and a solvent H2O molecule. Both Co1 and Co2 centers are six-coordinated and show distorted octahedral {CoN2O4} or {CoO6} geometries, respectively (a). Co1 center is surrounded by three oxygen and one nitrogen atom from three individual μ4-L3– blocks, one N atom from the μ2-4,4′-bipy ligand, and an oxygen atom from H2O ligand. Co2 center is bound by two oxygen atoms coming from two distinct μ4-L3– blocks and four oxygen donors of H2O ligands. Distances of the Co–O and Co–N bonds are 2.034(5)–2.148(5) and 2.148(5)–2.190(5) Å, respectively; these correlate with those observed in related cobalt derivatives. In 9, the L3– spacers show a μ4-bridging mode (mode VII, ), with the COO groups adopting the η1:η0 monodentate and μ2-η1:η1 bidentate fashions, respectively. In μ4-L3–, dihedral angle between the aromatic rings attains 33.57°. Carboxylate groups of the μ4-L3– blocks interlink the adjacent cobalt atoms to result in a dimeric Co2 subunit with a Co···Co separation of 4.402(2) Å (b). The adjacent Co2 subunits are further interconnected by the μ4-L3– blocks and μ2-4,4′-bipy linkers into a 3D MOF (c). This framework structure has channels of the 5.907 × 9.467 Å2 dimension if calculated using atom-to-atom distances. After the elimination of H2O moieties (both ligands and solvent), PLATON analysis furnishes a network’s free volume of 8.0% (relatively to the total crystal volume). From a topological perspective, an underlying 3D net of 9 is constructed from the 4-connected μ4-L nodes and Co1 nodes (these are topologically equivalent), as well as 2-connected 4,4′-bipy and Co2 linkers (d). This net can be described as a uninodal 4-connected framework of the sra (SrAl2) topology; point symbol is (42.63.8).

elements.content: Ligands obtained as a result of the deprotonation of 5-(6-carboxypyridin-3-yl)­isophthalic acid (H3L) during the hydrothermal synthesis of compounds 1–10 show seven different coordination modes (). By varying the molar ratio between NaOH and H3L in the course of the hydrothermal synthesis, the pyridine–tricarboxylate block can lead to the formation of moieties having a different degree of deprotonation, namely, H2L–, HL2–, and L3–. For example, the 1:1 or 2:1 molar ratios between NaOH and H3L result in the H2L– and HL2– ligands in compounds 1–3. Bigger excess of sodium hydroxide (NaOH:H3L = 3:1) leads to a fully deprotonated ligand (L3–) in 4–10. In turn, the carboxylate groups of 5-(6-carboxypyridin-3-yl)­isophthalate ligand can show four different coordination fashions, η1:η0 monodentate; η1:η1 and μ2-η1:η1 bidentate; and μ2-η2:η1 tridentate; whereas the pyridyl nitrogen atom behaves as an N-donor for metal­(II) centers in all products. An important feature of the H2L–/ HL2–/ L3– blocks concerns a possibility of the rotation of carbon–carbon single bond that connects the phenyl and pyridyl rings, resulting in dihedral angles varying from 6.01° to 34.92°. This feature makes these organic blocks rather flexible to fit to the metal-ion coordination geometry in the course of the hydrothermal synthesis. Besides, it should be mentioned that products 4 and 8 (5 and 9, 6 and 10) were isolated under the same hydrothermal conditions except in the presence of 4,4′-bipy during the synthesis of MOF 8 (9 and 10). Their structural differences can be attributed to the template (in 8 and 10) or coordination (in 9) effects of 4,4′-bipy. Interestingly, MOFs 6 and 10 are isomeric. All these observations suggest that various factors (e.g., molar ratio of NaOH and H3L, presence of ancillary ligands, and nature of metal nodes) strongly influence the generation process and the resulting structures of the obtained CPs or MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Diverse Coordination Modes of H2L-/ HL2-/ L3- Moieties and Comparison of Structures

Ligands obtained as a result of the deprotonation of 5-(6-carboxypyridin-3-yl)isophthalic acid (H3L) during the hydrothermal synthesis of compounds 1-10 show seven different coordination modes (). By varying the molar ratio between NaOH and H3L in the course of the hydrothermal synthesis, the pyridine-tricarboxylate block can lead to the formation of moieties having a different degree of deprotonation, namely, H2L-, HL2-, and L3-. For example, the 1:1 or 2:1 molar ratios between NaOH and H3L result in the H2L- and HL2- ligands in compounds 1-3. Bigger excess of sodium hydroxide (NaOH:H3L = 3:1) leads to a fully deprotonated ligand (L3-) in 4-10. In turn, the carboxylate groups of 5-(6-carboxypyridin-3-yl)isophthalate ligand can show four different coordination fashions, η1:η0 monodentate; η1:η1 and μ2-η1:η1 bidentate; and μ2-η2:η1 tridentate; whereas the pyridyl nitrogen atom behaves as an N-donor for metal(II) centers in all products. An important feature of the H2L-/ HL2-/ L3- blocks concerns a possibility of the rotation of carbon-carbon single bond that connects the phenyl and pyridyl rings, resulting in dihedral angles varying from 6.01° to 34.92°. This feature makes these organic blocks rather flexible to fit to the metal-ion coordination geometry in the course of the hydrothermal synthesis. Besides, it should be mentioned that products 4 and 8 (5 and 9, 6 and 10) were isolated under the same hydrothermal conditions except in the presence of 4,4'-bipy during the synthesis of MOF 8 (9 and 10). Their structural differences can be attributed to the template (in 8 and 10) or coordination (in 9) effects of 4,4'-bipy. Interestingly, MOFs 6 and 10 are isomeric. All these observations suggest that various factors (e.g., molar ratio of NaOH and H3L, presence of ancillary ligands, and nature of metal nodes) strongly influence the generation process and the resulting structures of the obtained CPs or MOFs.

elements.content: PXRD patterns of the bulk samples 1–10 are in very good agreement with the patterns simulated using the data from single-crystal X-ray diffraction (Figure S1, ), thus supporting phase purity of the obtained bulk products. To evaluate thermal stability of compounds 1–10, TGA curves were measured under N2 atmosphere (Figure S2, ). TGA of 1 and 2 shows that the samples remain stable until 128 and 342 °C, respectively. Compound 3 shows a release of two water molecules (exptl, 6.3%; calcd, 6.5%) from 42 to 168 °C, followed by the decomposition at 288 °C. Compound 4 shows only one thermal effect in the 35–263 °C temperature interval, being associated with the release of two solvent H2O moieties and seven H2O ligands (exptl, 18.3%; calcd, 18.2%); remaining solid starts to decompose at 364 °C. In the case of 5, weight loss corresponding to the removal of two solvent and six coordinated H2O molecules is seen from 37 to 176 °C (exptl, 16.4%; calcd, 16.2%); decomposition of the resulting solid starts at 341 °C. Compound 6 exhibits one weight loss effect in the 30–105 °C interval, corresponding to removal of two lattice water molecules and six H2O ligands (exptl, 15.9%; calcd, 16.2%); remaining solid starts to decompose at 283 °C. The MOF 7 loses two solvent and four coordinated H2O moieties between 42 and 146 °C (exptl, 12.2%; calcd, 12.4%); dehydrated sample starts to decompose at 372 °C. Compound 8 exhibits an elimination of four solvent and six coordinated H2O moieties in the 38–217 °C temperature interval (exptl, 19.5%; calcd, 19.7%); decomposition then starts only at 407 °C. Compound 9 shows the release of two solvent and six coordinated H2O moieties in the 42–220 °C interval (exptl, 13.5%; calcd, 13.8%); decomposition of organic moieties starts then at 306 °C. For MOF 10, a thermal effect (54–258 °C) is associated with the elimination of two lattice H2O molecules and six water ligands (exptl, 15.9%; calcd, 16.2%); heating above 278 °C results in the decomposition of a sample.

In the case of 5, weight loss corresponding to the removal of two solvent and six coordinated H2O molecules is seen from 37 to 176 °C (exptl, 16.4%; calcd, 16.2%); decomposition of the resulting solid starts at 341 °C. Compound 6 exhibits one weight loss effect in the 30-105 °C interval, corresponding to removal of two lattice water molecules and six H2O ligands (exptl, 15.9%; calcd, 16.2%); remaining solid starts to decompose at 283 °C. The MOF 7 loses two solvent and four coordinated H2O moieties between 42 and 146 °C (exptl, 12.2%; calcd, 12.4%); dehydrated sample starts to decompose at 372 °C. Compound 8 exhibits an elimination of four solvent and six coordinated H2O moieties in the 38-217 °C temperature interval (exptl, 19.5%; calcd, 19.7%); decomposition then starts only at 407 °C. Compound 9 shows the release of two solvent and six coordinated H2O moieties in the 42-220 °C interval (exptl, 13.5%; calcd, 13.8%); decomposition of organic moieties starts then at 306 °C. For MOF 10, a thermal effect (54-258 °C) is associated with the elimination of two lattice H2O molecules and six water ligands (exptl, 15.9%; calcd, 16.2%); heating above 278 °C results in the decomposition of a sample.

elements.content: Emission spectra of H3L, products 1 and 7 (Cd and Zn derivatives, respectively), were run at ambient temperature in the solid state (). Uncoordinated H3L reveals weak photoluminescence with a maximum of emission at 412 nm if excited at 340 nm. In the case of metal containing samples, emission bands having superior (1) or significantly superior (7) intensity were detected, showing a maximum at 419 nm (λex = 340 nm) for 1 or 408 nm (λex = 340 nm) for 7. All these bands most likely correspond to intraligand (π* → n or π* → π) emissions. Luminescence enhancement in 1 and 7 in comparison with H3L is related to the interaction of ligands with metal ions. As a result, ligand rigidity increases and the energy loss due to radiationless decay declines. A stronger luminescent intensity of 7 relatively to 1 is probably governed by the differences in their structures. In fact, the H2L– moieties behave as μ2-linkers in 1, while in 7 the L3– spacers feature an intricate μ5-coordination fashion. The latter makes the ligand more rigid, allowing to decrease a vibration-induced deactivation. The observed photoluminescence of 7 indicates that this Zn­(II) MOF can become an interesting candidate for applications in the field of photoactive materials.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

Emission spectra of H3L, products 1 and 7 (Cd and Zn derivatives, respectively), were run at ambient temperature in the solid state (). Uncoordinated H3L reveals weak photoluminescence with a maximum of emission at 412 nm if excited at 340 nm. In the case of metal containing samples, emission bands having superior (1) or significantly superior (7) intensity were detected, showing a maximum at 419 nm (λex = 340 nm) for 1 or 408 nm (λex = 340 nm) for 7. All these bands most likely correspond to intraligand (π* → n or π* → π) emissions. Luminescence enhancement in 1 and 7 in comparison with H3L is related to the interaction of ligands with metal ions. As a result, ligand rigidity increases and the energy loss due to radiationless decay declines. A stronger luminescent intensity of 7 relatively to 1 is probably governed by the differences in their structures. In fact, the H2L- moieties behave as μ2-linkers in 1, while in 7 the L3- spacers feature an intricate μ5-coordination fashion. The latter makes the ligand more rigid, allowing to decrease a vibration-induced deactivation. The observed photoluminescence of 7 indicates that this Zn(II) MOF can become an interesting candidate for applications in the field of photoactive materials.

elements.content: Investigation of magnetic susceptibility under variable temperatures studies were performed in the 2–300 K interval on powder samples of compounds 3–6 and 8–10 (). For a manganese­(II) dimer 3, as shown in , the χM T value of 4.50 cm3·mol–1·K at ambient temperature is approaching the value (4.38 cm3·mol–1·K) corresponding to one magnetically isolated high-spin manganese­(II) ion (S Mn = 5/2, g = 2.0). On lowering the temperature, the χM T values go gradually down to reach a dispersed minimum of 4.48 cm3·mol–1·K at 19 K. After this temperature, they abruptly decrease to give 4.25 cm3·mol–1·K at 2 K. In the 2–300 K range, the magnetic susceptibilities are fitted to Curie–Weiss law having the following parameters: C = 4.41 cm3·mol–1·K and θ = −4.77 K. Such results are indicative of a weak antiferromagnetic interaction within two adjacent manganese­(II) centers. We attempted to fit the obtained magnetic data for 3 by applying an expression for a dimanganese­(II) unit: H = −2S 1 S 2. Here, N, k, and β constants have their usual meaning.χ = 2Ng 2β2 A/KTB where A = exp ( J / k T ) + 5 exp ( 3 J / k T ) + 14 exp ( 6 J / k T ) + 30 exp ( 10 J / k T ) + 55 exp ( 15 J / k T ) B = 1 + 3 exp ( J / k T ) + 5 exp ( 3 J / k T ) + 7 exp ( 6 J / k T ) + 9 exp ( 10 J / k T ) + 11 exp ( 15 J / k T )

Magnetic Properties

Investigation of magnetic susceptibility under variable temperatures studies were performed in the 2-300 K interval on powder samples of compounds 3-6 and 8-10 (). For a manganese(II) dimer 3, as shown in , the χM T value of 4.50 cm3⋅mol-1⋅K at ambient temperature is approaching the value (4.38 cm3⋅mol-1⋅K) corresponding to one magnetically isolated high-spin manganese(II) ion (S Mn = 5/2, g = 2.0). On lowering the temperature, the χM T values go gradually down to reach a dispersed minimum of 4.48 cm3⋅mol-1⋅K at 19 K. After this temperature, they abruptly decrease to give 4.25 cm3⋅mol-1⋅K at 2 K. In the 2-300 K range, the magnetic susceptibilities are fitted to Curie-Weiss law having the following parameters: C = 4.41 cm3⋅mol-1⋅K and θ = -4.77 K. Such results are indicative of a weak antiferromagnetic interaction within two adjacent manganese(II) centers. We attempted to fit the obtained magnetic data for 3 by applying an expression for a dimanganese(II) unit: H = -2S 1 S 2. Here, N, k, and β constants have their usual meaning.χ = 2Ng 2β2 A/KTB where    A = exp  ( J / k T )  + 5  exp  ( 3 J / k T )  + 14  exp  ( 6 J / k T )  + 30  exp  ( 10 J / k T )  + 55  exp  ( 15 J / k T )         B = 1 + 3  exp  ( J / k T )  + 5  exp  ( 3 J / k T )  + 7  exp  ( 6 J / k T )  + 9  exp  ( 10 J / k T )  + 11  exp  ( 15 J / k T )

elements.content:
The best fitting gives J = −2.67 cm–1, g = 2.05, and R = 4.56 × 10–5. Negative J value confirms the presence of a weak antiferromagnetic coupling among two neighboring manganese­(II) atoms.

For the Mn­(II) metal–organic networks 4 and 8, the χM T values at 300 K are 13.24 cm3·mol–1·K for 4 and 12.82 cm3·mol–1·K for 8. These values are rather close to the value (13.11 cm3·mol–1·K) that correpsponds to three magnetically isolated high-spin manganese­(II) ions (S Mn = 5/2, g = 2.0). Decrease of χM T upon lowering temperature should indicate a dominant interaction of antiferromagnetic nature. In the 2–300 K range, magnetic susceptibility is in accordance with Curie–Weiss law, showing the following parameters: C = 13.93 cm3·mol–1·K, θ = −17.35 K for 4, and C = 12.71 cm3·mol–1·K, θ = −2.77 K for 8. Negative θ and the χM T decrease are indicative of the global antiferromagnetic coupling within the Mn3 subunit in 4. In the structure of 4, only one kind of the pathway for magnetic exchange is evident within the Mn3 subunit, namely, through the μ2-η1:η1-carboxylate (syn–anti) bridges (b). This pathway is believed to be responsible for the global exchange of an antiferromagnetic nature. Magnetic data for 4 were fitted by applying the expression for linear type of trimanganese­(II) cores: Ĥ = − 2 ∑ i = 1 n ∑ j > i n J i j S⃗ i S⃗ j Ĥ = − 2 J 12 S⃗ 1 S⃗ 2 − 2 J 23 S⃗ 2 S⃗ 3 − 2 J 13 S⃗ 1 S⃗ 3 χ t = N β 2 g 2 3 k T × ∑ S S T ( S T + 1 ) ( 2 S T + 1 ) e − E ( S T ) / k T ∑ S ( 2 S T + 1 ) e − E ( S T ) / k T χ m = χ t 1 − ( 2 z J ′ / N g 2 β 2 ) χ t where J 12 = J 23 = J 1, J 13 = J 2 (J 12 and J 23 stand for exchange interactions involving a “central” and two “outer” manganese­(II) atoms; J 2 stands for magnetic interaction between the “outer” manganese­(II) centers in a Mn3 subunit), zJ′ stands for an intercluster coupling constant in 2D coordination polymer. Such a model shows rather satisfactory results; superexchange parameters are J 1/k B = −1.58 K, J 2/k B = 0.41 K, zJ′/ k B= −0.26 K, and g = 2.01. Agreement factor is defined by R = ∑(χm T exp – m T calc)2/∑(χm T exp)2 is 6.58 × 10–5. The obtained data support an antiferromagnetic coupling within a Mn3 subunit. However, inercluster magnetic exchange (zJ′) is low, showing that the interactions between two Ni3 subunits are weak. This can be explained by a long distance [9.151(4) Å] that separates the neighboring Ni3 cores.

elements.content: For cobalt­(II) MOF 9, χM T at ambient temperature (10.92 cm3·mol–1·K) is much larger than the expected value (5.61 cm3·mol–1·K) for three high-spin cobalt­(II) ions that are magnetically isolated (S = 3/2). This fact reveals a considerable orbital contribution. The χM T values steadily go down on lowering the temperature to attain a minimum (3.24 cm3·mol–1·K at 2 K). In the 150–300 K range, magnetic susceptibility fits to Curie–Weiss law (C = 11.30 cm3·mol–1·K and θ = −20.4 K). In the Co2 subunit of 9, magnetic coupling among two Co­(II) atoms is transmitted via two μ2-η1:η1 carboxylate bridges.

elements.content: Ground state of a high-spin octahedral Co2+ ion corresponds to 4T1g, being splitted into sextet, quartet, and Kramers doublet (Hamiltonian H = −λLS). λ and L are a spin–orbit coupling parameter and an electronic orbital operator, respectively. The χM expression for 9 is provided by the following equation χ Co = 8 N β 2 κ ( T − θ ) x [ 7 ( 3 − A ) 2 x 5 + 12 ( A + 2 ) 2 25 A + { 2 ( 11 − 2 A ) x 45 + 176 ( A + 2 ) 2 675 A } exp ( − 5 A x / 2 ) + { ( Α + 5 ) 2 x 9 − 20 ( Α + 2 ) 2 27 Α } x exp ( − 4 A x ) ] / [ 3 + 2 exp ( − 5 A x / 2 ) + exp ( − 4 A x ) ] wherein x = λ/kT, whereas A represents a measure of the strength of crystal field. Best fit of magnetic susceptibility above 40 K results in the following parameters: λ = −45 cm–1, A = 1.12, and θ = −1.01 K. Fitting value of θ confirms an antiferromagnetic exchange within dimers in 9.

elements.content: In the case of nickel­(II) derivative 6, the χM T value at room temperature, 2.99 cm3·mol–1·K, is in agreement with that of 3.00 cm3 mol–1 K. The latter value is calculated for three magnetically isolated nickel­(II) centers (S Ni= 1, g = 2.0). Upon decreasing the temperature, χM T goes gradually down to give a minimum of 2.80 cm3·mol–1·K at 52 K. Then, χM T abruptly increases until a sharp maximum (2.90 cm3·mol–1·K) at 9.5 K, and finally goes down even more rapidly on additional cooling. In the 2–300 K temperature interval, magnetic susceptibility fits to Curie–Weiss law (C = 3.20 cm3·mol–1·K and θ = −15.1 K). Given a separation of the neighboring Ni3 subunits, negative θ as well as a χM T decrease are related to the global antiferromagnetic coupling among nickel­(II) centers in the Ni3 subunit.

elements.content: We prepared and characterized a series of new metal­(II) (Cd, Ni, Mn, Co, and Zn) coordination compounds derived from a versatile and multifunctional pyridine-tricarboxylate N,O-building block, 5-(6-carboxypyridin-3-yl)­isophthalic acid (H3L). Thus, by choosing various metal­(II) sources and varying molar ratios between reagents and/or introducing aromatic auxiliary N-donor ligands, we were able to assemble a high variety of novel coordination compounds using water as a reaction medium. Their structural types range from very complex 3D metal–organic frameworks (5 and 7–10) and 2D coordination polymers (1, 4, and 6) to discrete 0D monomer (2) and dimer (3). Interestingly, structures of 1–3 show further extension [0D → 3D (2 and 3) and 2D → 3D (1)] to give H-bonded nets if strong hydrogen bonds are taken into consideration. Moreover, 4,4′-bipyridine can tune the structures by its coordination or template effect. The generated products 1–10 thus not only represent distinct structural features and dimensionalities but also reveal a high diversity of topological types. These include the sql (in 1), 3,4L83 (in 4 and 6), tcs (in 5, 8, and 10), 3,4,5T95 (in 7), and sra (in 9) topological metal–organic nets, as well as the 3,10T3 (in 3) and a topologically unique net (in 2) H-bonded frameworks. Thus, the work also contributes toward the classification and identification of new topological motifs in crystal engineering research. Moreover, for selected compounds, luminescent and magnetic properties were investigated. In particular, compound 7 exhibits an intense violet emission in the solid state at ambient temperature. Investigation of magnetic susceptibility indicate the interactions of an antiferromagnetic type among metal­(II) centers in 3–6 and 8–10. Further exploration of 5-(6-carboxypyridin-3-yl)­isophthalic acid and derived phenyl-pyridine multicarboxylate building blocks for assembling different types of functional MOFs or CPs will be continued.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We prepared and characterized a series of new metal(II) (Cd, Ni, Mn, Co, and Zn) coordination compounds derived from a versatile and multifunctional pyridine-tricarboxylate N,O-building block, 5-(6-carboxypyridin-3-yl)isophthalic acid (H3L). Thus, by choosing various metal(II) sources and varying molar ratios between reagents and/or introducing aromatic auxiliary N-donor ligands, we were able to assemble a high variety of novel coordination compounds using water as a reaction medium. Their structural types range from very complex 3D metal-organic frameworks (5 and 7-10) and 2D coordination polymers (1, 4, and 6) to discrete 0D monomer (2) and dimer (3). Interestingly, structures of 1-3 show further extension [0D → 3D (2 and 3) and 2D → 3D (1)] to give H-bonded nets if strong hydrogen bonds are taken into consideration. Moreover, 4,4'-bipyridine can tune the structures by its coordination or template effect. The generated products 1-10 thus not only represent distinct structural features and dimensionalities but also reveal a high diversity of topological types. These include the sql (in 1), 3,4L83 (in 4 and 6), tcs (in 5, 8, and 10), 3,4,5T95 (in 7), and sra (in 9) topological metal-organic nets, as well as the 3,10T3 (in 3) and a topologically unique net (in 2) H-bonded frameworks. Thus, the work also contributes toward the classification and identification of new topological motifs in crystal engineering research. Moreover, for selected compounds, luminescent and magnetic properties were investigated. In particular, compound 7 exhibits an intense violet emission in the solid state at ambient temperature. Investigation of magnetic susceptibility indicate the interactions of an antiferromagnetic type among metal(II) centers in 3-6 and 8-10. Further exploration of 5-(6-carboxypyridin-3-yl)isophthalic acid and derived phenyl-pyridine multicarboxylate building blocks for assembling different types of functional MOFs or CPs will be continued.

cln_elements.content:
Compound 3 exhibits a discrete dinuclear structure with its asymmetric unit containing one Mn­(II) atom, one μ2-HL2–, and one 1,10-phenanthroline moiety, one H2O ligand, and one water molecule of crystallization. A 6-coordinate Mn1 center exhibits distorted octahedral {MnN3O3} geometry which is filled by one N atom and two carboxylate O atoms coming from two different μ2-HL2– blocks, one O atom from water ligand, and two N atoms of a 1,10-phenanthroline moiety (a). Distances of the Mn–O bonds [2.125(2)–2.133(2) Å] and the Mn–N bonds [2.261(3)–2.359(3) Å] are typical for such manganese­(II) compounds. In 3, the HL2– block shows a μ2-mode (mode III, ), wherein both deprotonated COO groups adopt a η1:η0 monodentate mode. Two aromatic rings in HL2– show a dihedral angle of 34.92°. In 3, the μ2-HL2– ligands connect the Mn1 atoms to give a Mn2 molecular unit having a Mn···Mn distance of 9.405(3) Å (a). These discrete Mn2 units and H2O molecules of crystallization are interconnected by means of the O–H···O H-bonds to give rise to an intricate three-dimensional supramolecular network (b, Table S3, ). This network was simplified to carry out the topological classification, resulting in the underlying binodal 3,10-connected net (c). This net has the 3,10T3 topology and is described by the (3.42)2(34.410.514.614.72.8) point symbol, wherein the (3.42) and (34.410.514.614.72.8) indices are those of the 3-conected H2O nodes and the 10-connected dimanganese­(II) molecular nodes, respectively.

The Zn–O [1.959(9)–2.229(6) Å] and Zn–N [2.034(8) Å] bond distances are in agreement with those reported for related zinc derivatives. In 7, the L3– block behaves as a μ5-spacer (mode VI, ) with its COO groups adopting η1:η0 monodentate, μ2-η1:η1 bidentate, and μ2-η2:η1 tridentate modes. In μ5-L3–, dihedral angle between aromatic rings attains 25.67°. Carboxylate groups of the μ5-L3– blocks multiply interconnect neighboring zinc atoms to give rise to an intricate 3D MOF structure (b). It contains channels of the 7.938 × 4.241 Å2 dimension if measured via atom-to-atom distances; these channels are filled with lattice H2O molecules. After the elimination of H2O molecules (both ligand and solvent), PLATON allowed to calculate a network’s free volume of 7.0% (relatively to the total crystal volume). From topological perspective, a simplified underlying three-dimensional network of 7 (c) is defined as a trinodal 3,4,5-connected net of the 3,4,5T95 topology. Point symbol of this net is (4.63.86)2(42.84)­(63)2, wherein the (4.63.86), (42.84), and (63)2 notations correspond to the 5-connected μ5-L nodes, 4-connected zinc­(II) nodes (based on disordered Zn2 atoms), and 3-connected Zn1 nodes, respectively.

PXRD Results and Thermal Analysis

PXRD patterns of the bulk samples 1–10 are in very good agreement with the patterns simulated using the data from single-crystal X-ray diffraction (Figure S1, ), thus supporting phase purity of the obtained bulk products. To evaluate thermal stability of compounds 1–10, TGA curves were measured under N2 atmosphere (Figure S2, ). TGA of 1 and 2 shows that the samples remain stable until 128 and 342 °C, respectively. Compound 3 shows a release of two water molecules (exptl, 6.3%; calcd, 6.5%) from 42 to 168 °C, followed by the decomposition at 288 °C. Compound 4 shows only one thermal effect in the 35–263 °C temperature interval, being associated with the release of two solvent H2O moieties and seven H2O ligands (exptl, 18.3%; calcd, 18.2%); remaining solid starts to decompose at 364 °C. In the case of 5, weight loss corresponding to the removal of two solvent and six coordinated H2O molecules is seen from 37 to 176 °C (exptl, 16.4%; calcd, 16.2%); decomposition of the resulting solid starts at 341 °C. Compound 6 exhibits one weight loss effect in the 30–105 °C interval, corresponding to removal of two lattice water molecules and six H2O ligands (exptl, 15.9%; calcd, 16.2%); remaining solid starts to decompose at 283 °C. The MOF 7 loses two solvent and four coordinated H2O moieties between 42 and 146 °C (exptl, 12.2%; calcd, 12.4%); dehydrated sample starts to decompose at 372 °C. Compound 8 exhibits an elimination of four solvent and six coordinated H2O moieties in the 38–217 °C temperature interval (exptl, 19.5%; calcd, 19.7%); decomposition then starts only at 407 °C. Compound 9 shows the release of two solvent and six coordinated H2O moieties in the 42–220 °C interval (exptl, 13.5%; calcd, 13.8%); decomposition of organic moieties starts then at 306 °C. For MOF 10, a thermal effect (54–258 °C) is associated with the elimination of two lattice H2O molecules and six water ligands (exptl, 15.9%; calcd, 16.2%); heating above 278 °C results in the decomposition of a sample.

For cobalt­(II) MOF 9, χM T at ambient temperature (10.92 cm3·mol–1·K) is much larger than the expected value (5.61 cm3·mol–1·K) for three high-spin cobalt­(II) ions that are magnetically isolated (S = 3/2). This fact reveals a considerable orbital contribution. The χM T values steadily go down on lowering the temperature to attain a minimum (3.24 cm3·mol–1·K at 2 K). In the 150–300 K range, magnetic susceptibility fits to Curie–Weiss law (C = 11.30 cm3·mol–1·K and θ = −20.4 K). In the Co2 subunit of 9, magnetic coupling among two Co­(II) atoms is transmitted via two μ2-η1:η1 carboxylate bridges.

In the case of nickel­(II) derivative 6, the χM T value at room temperature, 2.99 cm3·mol–1·K, is in agreement with that of 3.00 cm3 mol–1 K. The latter value is calculated for three magnetically isolated nickel­(II) centers (S Ni= 1, g = 2.0). Upon decreasing the temperature, χM T goes gradually down to give a minimum of 2.80 cm3·mol–1·K at 52 K. Then, χM T abruptly increases until a sharp maximum (2.90 cm3·mol–1·K) at 9.5 K, and finally goes down even more rapidly on additional cooling. In the 2–300 K temperature interval, magnetic susceptibility fits to Curie–Weiss law (C = 3.20 cm3·mol–1·K and θ = −15.1 K). Given a separation of the neighboring Ni3 subunits, negative θ as well as a χM T decrease are related to the global antiferromagnetic coupling among nickel­(II) centers in the Ni3 subunit.
